com.facebook.buck.junit

Class BuckBlockJUnit4ClassRunner

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.junit.runner.Runner
      • org.junit.runners.ParentRunner<FrameworkMethod>
        • org.junit.runners.BlockJUnit4ClassRunner
          • com.facebook.buck.junit.BuckBlockJUnit4ClassRunner
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Describable, Filterable, Sortable

    public class BuckBlockJUnit4ClassRunner
extends BlockJUnit4ClassRunner
    JUnit-4-compatible test class runner that supports the concept of a "default timeout." If the value of defaultTestTimeoutMillis passed to the constructor is non-zero, then it will be used in place of Test.timeout() if Test.timeout() returns zero.

    The superclass, BlockJUnit4ClassRunner, was introduced in JUnit 4.5 as a published API that was designed to be extended.

      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Result runTest(Method testMethod)
      Convenience method to run a single test method under JUnit.
      protected Statement withPotentialTimeout(FrameworkMethod method, Object test, Statement next)
      Override the default timeout behavior so that when no timeout is specified in the Test annotation, the timeout specified by the constructor will be used (if it has been set).

        public Result runTest(Method testMethod)

      • withPotentialTimeout

        protected Statement withPotentialTimeout(FrameworkMethod method,
                             Object test,
                             Statement next)
        Override the default timeout behavior so that when no timeout is specified in the Test annotation, the timeout specified by the constructor will be used (if it has been set).

        IMPORTANT In JUnit 4.11, this method is tagged as deprecated with the note: "Will be private soon: use Rules instead." That suggests that we should override BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.getTestRules(Object) so that it includes an additional Timeout, if appropriate. However, Timeout was not introduced until JUnit 4.7 and TestRule was not introduced until JUnit 4.9, so the current solution is more backwards-compatible. We will likely have to revisit this in the future.

        Overrides:
        withPotentialTimeout in class BlockJUnit4ClassRunner
